ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Daily zoom class
The learning was mostly discussion-based. The professor would occasionally semi-lecture when explaining new grammar, but that was still interactive, and certainly in the minority.
Throughout the course we also had daily homework that included a course-packet and audio files online. There was also daily reading, some quizzes, tests, and a few movies.
There were a few asynchronous classes wherein we participated in discussions or watched films.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Really learned how to read and write in French
I improved my French grammar and speaking skills. I was exposed to some classic works of French film and literature.
My French grammar and conversation improved a lot

I got much more comfortable conversing and explaining things in French. The class was taught entirely in French, and this really helped shore up the basics. While much of the grammar in the course was review, it nonetheless went deeper than many of my previous classes had gone, and it was still helpful to learn it again. The exposure to French literature definitely broadened my understanding of the language as well as French history and culture.
I have learned so much in this class. I am now more confident in having conversations in french as well as my writing and auditory comprehension skills.

I thought this was a very well-taught course. The workload of the course was high, but I felt like it was important to absorb the material. I feel like the course helped a lot with basic grammar and using that to produce better writing and speech.
speaking and writing French
I was able to continue learning french grammar as well as improve my french reading skills. Along with this, I was able to improve my speaking skills through class discussions.

This course expanded my French grammar knowledge, enhanced my conversational skills, and made me more confident in speaking French. It also exposed me to a wide variety of texts and developed my reading comprehension skills.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: In all of my classes at Yale, we begin by introducing ourselves and our pronouns. It seems the French department doesn't do that. And as a nonbinary student, I would have appreciated the vocabulary to identify myself and others using the appropriate pronouns. But the FREN 130 curriculum only teaches il and elle. I felt uncomfortable on the (luckily) few occasions that I was referred to by masculine pronouns, and think that the onus shouldn't have been on me (or anyone of non-normative gender identity/expression) to ask for pronoun intros. It should just be the standard. Once that's accomplished, it'd be cool if there were a unit about the movement for gender inclusive French (and, more broadly, the rigidity of French language, its connection to national identity/values, the absurd bureaucracy of the Acadmie Franaise), but this brings me to my next point: the rigidity of instruction (or the way that the course packet structured pretty much everything, including whether or not there's a brief lesson on French language/culture). Does the CP ever change? And what if the audio programs don't support your learning style? As a visual learner, I sometimes found it difficult to follow the recordings, and would have appreciated to just see the rules on the page. Also, there seemed to be an excessive number of practice sentences in the CP that involved some variation of "Il a tu un Arabe." What's up with that? I get that it's a central element of L'etranger's plot, but it appeared *that* many times that it began to feel weird and racialized on the Department's end.
There is a lot of daily homework but it helps practice and not really need to study when we have evaluations.

Strengths include a very open and welcoming class environment as well as a curriculum that taught things in many different ways. The weakness of this course was that the homework programs occasionally felt like busy work and confusing instead of teaching the content. It was annoying not to be able to skip forward or backward in the audio files, so things could take much longer than they needed to. Much of the confusion could be cleared up if we were given note sheets or something akin to what we received in the end-of-unit review packets while we were learning the content instead of at the end.
My professor was the best professor I have ever had in any Yale taught course. A credit to the department
n/a

One weakness was that at times there wasn't always ready answers for the grammar practice with did with the audio and the course-packet. This made it hard to know if one was answering the questions correctly. However, the course's strength was the books and movies chosen for viewing and reading as well as the prolonged discussions we had about the materials in class. Although it is difficult to conduct a language class online, I would have enjoyed doing more of a variety of activities in class rather than mostly grammar discussions. More activities would have been enjoyable along with the discussions on the material.

It was great meeting daily and having a clear structure to things. I also liked that there was a variety of different learning modes. The homework load was difficult to manage at times, but the homework helped greatly with unit test preparation.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I appreciated that on some days, instead of virtual class, we had assignments to complete at home (e.g. watching a film, completing a quiz or writing assignment). But, on the whole, this was insufficient to combat Zoom/computer fatigue. As it is, it's draining to have all your classes via Zoomparticularly if one of your classes meets every single morning. So, it'd be nice if the attendance policy could be somewhat relaxed, or if there were more opportunities to complete an assignment on our own time in place of a live class meeting.
Online discussions still worked through zoom. Breakout rooms worked best.
I think this class did a great job of fostering participation even in an online format. I truly felt like I was in the classroom.
n/a

I feel as if all of the practices geared towards virtual learning succeeded. It was nice to have a live virtual class as well as the occasional day off from class. I would have liked more opportunities to get to know my classmates though in an organic manner. Possibly a class viewing of a film or an in person event for those on campus.

I thought that taking a language course during the pandemic would be extremely difficult, but the faculty did a great job making it work. The daily Zoom classes worked well, the online resources were easy to navigate, and all of the asynchronous activities went smoothly. It would've been great to have more opportunities to collaborate with others in small groups.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes definitely. Although it is a lot of work if you are committed to improving you French it is a great class.

I would recommend this course. The homework is time-consuming but very organized. The readings and discussions can be fun. The teaching staff is very honest about what is on the assessments and never tries to trick you.
Absolutely, I loved this course and have learned so much.
I would recommend to anyone who really wants to learn French.
Yes I would highly recommend it
no

I would recommend this course to another student because I really enjoyed the books we read, movies we watched, and discussions that we had. I thought that every aspect of the course was also very accessible for our french level.
Yes! This was one of my favorite courses of the term. The workload is intense, but you learn a lot.
